name: Animal Bites
description: If you or someone else suffered a bite from a dog or cat, please report it by completing theÂ Animal Bite Report.

children.text: If you or someone else suffered a bite from a dog or cat, please report it by completing the  Animal Bite Report . You will be asked to leave your name and phone number so that Animal Services can be dispatched to investigate. All animal bite cases should be referred to the Florida Department of Health in Miami-Dade County at 305-324-2400.

keywords: Animal Bite, Report Animal Bite

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you are 18 years of age or older, you can adopt a pet from our Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

onlineChannels.label: Animal Bite & Potential Rabies Exposure Incidents

name: Rabies
description: Rabies attacks the brain and spinal cord, and leads to death if precautions are not taken to prevent contraction.

children.text: Rabies is a disease caused by a virus. The word "rabies" comes from a Latin word that means "to rage" because rabid animals sometimes act as if they are angry. Rabies attacks the brain and spinal cord, and leads to death if precautions are not taken to prevent contraction. Any mammal can get rabies. The most common are raccoons, skunks, bats, foxes, and coyotes. Domestic mammals can also get rabies. According to the Florida Department of Health , outside cats are by far the most common domestic animal found to have rabies in the State of Florida largely because they are not kept up-to-date on vaccinations. Although rare, humans can also get rabies from infected animals. An animal gets rabies from saliva, usually from a bite of an animal that has the disease. You cannot get rabies from blood.  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention , the number of rabies-related human dealths in United States has declined from more than 100 annually at the turn of the century to one or two per year in the 1990's. Modern day vaccination efforts have proven nearly 100 percent successful. In the United States, human fatalities associated with rabies occur in people who fail to seek medical assistance, usually because they were unaware of their exposure. If you think you are infected, a doctor will assess the risk for rabies exposure. If necessary, a regimen of one dose of immune globulin and five doses of rabies vaccine over a 28-day period will be given. Current vaccines are relatively painless and are given in your arm, like a flu or tetanus vaccine. Read about rabies vaccination and vaccination packages offered by Animal Services.

keywords: Animal bite, rabies

onlineChannels.label: Animal Bite & Potential Rabies Exposure Incidents

name: Animal Cruelty
description: Animal Services investigates suspected cases of animal cruelty on dogs and cats.

children.text: You can report neglect or abuse of any animal in Miami-Dade County. Animal cruelty is when a person causes unjustified harm, pain, or suffering to an animal or neglects an animal's care by not providing it with proper food, water, medical care, or suitable shelter.

keywords: Animals, Animal Cruelty, Animal Abuse

name: Dangerous Dogs Registration
description: An owner whose dog has been declared dangerous must register the dog with Animal Services within 14 days of that declaration.

children.text: An owner whose dog has been declared dangerous must register the dog with Animal Services within 14 days of that declaration. For a dog deemed as dangerous in another state or county that is moving to Miami-Dade County, the owner must register the dog with Animal Services and provide documentation.

keywords: dangerous dog, aggressive dog, attack, dogs that are dangerous, dogs attacking people, threatening dogs

children.text: Dangerous Dog Annual Registration Fee $125.00 As a prerequisite to registration, the dog owner must supply: Proof of current rabies vaccination Proof of current Miami-Dade County tag Proof that the animal has a microchip, and that the microchip has been registered with the national registry associated with the microchip Proof that the animal has been sterilized Photos of the enclosure the dog will be housed in Photos of signs at all entry points to the property advising both children and adults alike that a dangerous dog is on the property

Dangerous Dog Life Registration (non-transferrable) $500.00 As a prerequisite to registration, the dog owner must supply: Proof of current rabies vaccination Proof of current Miami-Dade County tag Proof that the animal has a microchip, and that the microchip has been registered with the national registry associated with the microchip Proof that the animal has been sterilized Photos of the enclosure the dog will be housed in Photos of signs at all entry points to the property advising both children and adults alike that a dangerous dog is on the property

name: Animal Licenses
description: Animal licenses are available for dogs and cats. Business licenses are required for pet breeders, kennels, pet dealers and groomers.

children.text: Licenses for Pet Owners Animal license tags are available for dogs and cats License tags are required for all dogs over four months of age. The dog must be registered with Miami-Dade County and wear the tag at all times Tags are available for cats, but they are not required. Since cats are clever enough to take off their collars, a microchip is recommended instead of a tag Animal Business Licenses Anyone who conducts a business that deals with animals in Miami-Dade County must obtain their license from Animal Services. Animal Services issues four types of business licenses depending on your needs. We have a groomer, hobby breeder, pet store and kennel license.

alternateNames: dog tag, cat tag, rabies tag, Dog license number, Dog license tag, Dog registration, Dog registration tags, Dog tag renewal, License tag renewal, Pet license, Pet registration, Rabies tag, Rabies vaccine number, Rabies vaccine tag number, Register dog, Register pets, Renew pet license, Renew tag, Replacement rabies tag, Tag lookup, Tag renewal, Tag renewal online

serviceImage.imageAlt: Animal licenses are available for dogs and cats. Business licenses are required for pet breeders, dealers kennels and groomers.

children.text: Now it is easy to check the expiration of your license tag by just putting in the full tag number along with the first letter. The tag will have a letter followed by six numbers. If you find a dog, you can also look up the owner's information by putting in the license tag information.

Purchase a dog  license (tag): Pet Adoption and Protection Center Your local veterinarian’s office Any one of the 311 Service Centers-only accept personal check, cashier's check or money order Through the mail-make check payable to Miami-Dade Animal Services You are not able to purchase or renew your dog's license online.

name: Animal Licenses & Tags
description: Animal licenses are available for dogs and cats. Business licenses are required for pet breeders, kennels, pet dealers and groomers.

children.text: Licenses for Pet Owners Animal license tags are available for dogs and cats. License tags are required for all dogs over four months of age. The dog must be registered with Miami-Dade County and wear the tag at all times. Tags are available for cats, but they are not required. Since cats are clever enough to take off their collars, a microchip is recommended instead of a tag. Animal Business Licenses In light of recent state legislation, Miami-Dade County’s Animal Services Department (ASD) no longer requires licenses for breeders, hobby breeders, guard dog services, kennel operators, mobile groomers, pet care centers and pet dealers. However, ASD still maintains applicable standards for those industries, pursuant to Chapter 5 of the Miami-Dade County Code. ASD also offers a voluntary certification program for a Certificate of Acknowledgement, designed to equip you with the tools and guidance needed to remain in compliance with code requirements.

keywords: Animal Licenses, pet tags, pet licenses, Animal License tags, dog tag, cat tag, rabies tag, Dog license number, Dog license tag, Dog registration, Dog registration tags, Dog tag renewal, License tag renewal, Pet license, Pet registration, Rabies tag, Rabies vaccine number, Rabies vaccine tag number, Register dog, Register pets, Renew pet license, Renew tag, Replacement rabies tag, Tag lookup, Tag renewal, Tag renewal online

name: Animal Nuisance
description: Any owner of an animal found to be causing a common nuisance, irritation, annoyance or bother to other persons or other animals may be fined.

children.text: Barking dogs or noisy birds may violate Ordinance 21-28 (4) (c) . If you would like to report a potential violation of the noise ordinance, you may call the Miami-Dade Police Department’s non-emergency line at 305-476-5423. Officers from the Neighborhood Resource Unit will respond and address accordingly. Once the police arrive at the violator's residence and they hear the dogs or animals, they can automatically issue a fine, which is $100. Failure to pay the fine will result in a lien on the home.  Homeowners who rent their property may be responsible for their tenant's dog or other animals. Please remind tenants to keep their dogs and other animals quiet because the homeowner will be ultimately responsible for payment of any fines. Please contain noisy birds. Keep barking dogs inside, muzzled, or trained not to bark or else you can get fined every time the police arrive at your home and hear barking dogs or any noisy animal. To report a potential noise violation: Call the Miami-Dade Sheriff's Office non-emergency line at 305-476-5423 Officers from the Neighborhood Resource Unit will respond to the complaint Important: If the officer arrives and hears the noise firsthand, they may issue a $100 fine on the spot Failure to pay the fine may result in a lien on the property Note for homeowners: If you are renting out your property, you may still be held responsible for fines caused by your tenant's noisy pets. Please remind tenants to: Keep dogs indoors, trained not to bark or properly muzzled Contain or quiet noisy birds or other loud animals Each time officers arrive and hear noise, a new fine may be issued. Report an Aggressive or Dangerous Dog If you or someone else is bitten by a dog: Call 911 immediately if the injury is severe or life-threatening Seek immediate medical attention If the attack has ended and there is no immediate danger, report the incident to Animal Services: Contact Us: Dial 311 or 305-468-5900 For hearing or speech disabilities, call Florida Relay at 711 Hours: Monday – Friday: 7 a.m. – 7 p.m. Saturday: 8 a.m. – 5 p.m. Closed Sundays and holidays You’ll need to provide: A description of the dog The location or address of where the aggressive dog resides The address of the person or pet injured What happens next: An Animal Control Officer will be dispatched to the dog owner's address A dangerous dog investigation will begin The dog may be quarantined for 10 days in the owner's home After 10 days, Animal Services Department will notify you of the investigation results Need Help? Submit a Service Request on an aggressive and dangerous dog or call 311. Download the 311 Direct app Apple Android

keywords: Animals, Animal Nuisance, barking dog, dangerous dog, loose farm animals

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you are 18 years of age or older, you can adopt a pet from our Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

name: Pet Adoption and Protection Center
description: Miami-Dade County's Pet Adoption and Protection Center is located at 3599 NW 79th Avenue in Doral.

children.text: The Miami-Dade Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center is located at 3599 NW 79th Avenue in Doral. Miami-Dade County's facility is a major milestone in accomplishing our goal to save the lives of homeless pets in our community. The design of the facility makes it a model of best practices in animal housing and prioritizes the adoption of pets. The facility offers a comfortable environment for homeless pets, those who care for them and the people looking to adopt a dog or cat. The facility offers the ability to expand our spay and neuter service which is a critical step in reaching our goal of a no kill Miami-Dade County.

alternateNames: animal services, pet adoption center, animal shelter

children.text: Spacious air-conditioned kennels Several outdoor canine exercise and play areas A community playroom for cats
Location: 3599 NW 79th Avenue, Doral, FL 33122 Site: 5.04 acres Building size: 70,000 square feet, more than double the size of the previous shelter

name: Animal Traps
description: Animal traps are used to humanely remove animals from private property.

children.text: Animal traps are used to humanely remove animals from private property. Once safely trapped, residents should bring cats and dogs to the Pet Adoption and Protection Center. Animals will be scanned for microchips and if found to have one, their owners will be contacted.

keywords: cat trap, dog trap, trap-neuter-return, Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return
alternateNames: cat trap, dog trap, trap-neuter-return, Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return

name: Animal Traps
description: Animal traps are used to humanely remove animals from private property.

children.text: Once safely trapped, residents should bring dogs and cats to the Pet Adoption and Protection Center in Doral, Miami-Dade County Animal Services' main location. Animals will be scanned for microchips and if found to have one, their owners will be contacted. If cats are trapped as part of the  Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return program, you can pick up the cat or choose to have the cat returned to you or to the area where it was picked up. Cats not picked up from the Pet Adoption and Protection Center after several days will be released back to the community from which they came. Injured or diseased cats are not released back into the community.

alternateNames: cat trap, dog trap, trap-neuter-return, Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return

children.text: Through the  Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return program, residents can borrow a trap from Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center in Doral to capture the cat. The cat traps are provided on a first-come, first-served basis and are available for free but do require a $50 refundable deposit. The traps must be returned within 10 days to receive a refund on your deposit. Once the cat has been captured, the resident should transport the cat to the Adoption and Protection Center to be sterilized, vaccinated and have it's ear tipped. Animal Services will not come to pick up the cat. After surgery and required recovery time, the resident can pick up the cat or choose to have the cat returned to them or to the area where it was picked up. Cats not picked up from the Pet Adoption and Protection Center after several days will be released back to the community from which they came. Injured or diseased cats are not released back into the community.

Animal control officers will try to capture stray dogs that have been reported to 311. If the dog is not captured at that time, a trap will be provided by Animal Services at no cost. When the dog has been trapped, call 311 to arrange for Animal Services to pick up the dog. Dog traps are not available at the Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

name: Breeder, Pet Store, Kennel and Groomer Complaints
description: To report complaints regarding unsanitary or unsafe conditions at breeders, pet stores, kennels, and groomers, including concerns about sick animals.

children.text: To report complaints regarding unsanitary or unsafe conditions at breeders, pet stores, kennels, and groomers, including concerns about sick animals, poor living conditions, or neglect. If you’ve noticed animals in poor conditions, dirty surroundings, or sick or neglected pets at a local pet store, breeder, kennel, or groomer, we want to hear from you. What You Can Report: Unsanitary cages or pens Sick or malnourished animals Overcrowding Foul odors or visible waste Lack of clean food and water Livestock Concerns? If your concern involves farm animals like horses, cows, goats or chickens, please contact: Miami-Dade Sheriff's Office Agriculture Patrol 305-252-8311 You’ll also be given the correct city contact number based on the animal's location. Concern About a Veterinarian? Veterinarians are regulated by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation (DBPR) . You can file a complaint if you believe a vet is engaging in unlicensed activity or neglectful practices. Visit: MyFloridaLicense.com Required Forms: DBPR-0070 – Complaint Form VM-4910 – Authorization to Release Patient Information Mail completed forms to: Department of Business and Professional Regulation Division of Regulation and Compliance – Consumer Services 1940 North Monroe Street Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0782 Phone: 850-487-1395 or 866-532-1440 Need Help? Submit a Service Request on a Breeder or Pet Store Complaint or call 311. Download the 311 Direct app Apple Android

keywords: Breeder / Pet Store / Kennel / Groomer Complaints

onlineChannels.label: Report Breeder or Pet Store Complaint

name: Dead or Injured Animal
description: Animal Services only picks up dead animals found on the public right-of-way and responds to injured animals as a priority.

children.text: Animal Services only picks up dead animals when the owner is unknown and the animal is on the public right-of-way. Dead animals should never be placed in a regular green garbage or blue recycling bins. Animal Services does not pick-up deceased owned animals. It is the pet owner's responsibility to transport the deceased pet to Animal Services or the County's landfill. Animal Services responds to injured animals as a priority. If you see a dog that has been possibly hit by a car, please contact us immediately.

keywords: dead animal, dead animal carcass disposal, dead  cat, dead dog, Dead Animal
alternateNames: dead animal in the street, dead animal on highway, dead animal in canal, animal carcass on the road, disposal, dead cat, dead dog, pick up dead animal, dead animal on public right of way

name: Foster a Pet Program
description: As a pet foster parent you can help save lives by caring for dogs and cats in your home.

children.text: As a pet foster parent, you can help save a life by caring for a cat or dog in your home until it is ready for adoption. Pet foster parents receive the training and supplies needed to help keep the animal healthy and socialized until it is ready for adoption. You can foster a pet for one week or several weeks, depending on the pet and their needs.

keywords: Pet Foster Parent Program, Fostering for Animal Services, Foster a Pet, Foster a Dog, Foster a Cat, Foster a Puppy, Foster a Kitten.
alternateNames: pet foster, cat foster, foster a cat, foster a dog, foster a puppy, foster a kitten

name: Animal Services Internship Program
description: Through professional mentoring, students will have the opportunity to prepare and develop skills to better position themselves for future job opportunities

children.text: Miami-Dade County’s Animal Services Department offers an Internship Program designed to enrich the academic studies of students in high school and college through observation and participating in daily shelter duties. Through professional mentoring, students will have the opportunity to prepare and develop skills to better position themselves for future job opportunities.

keywords: internship program, shelter internship, skill building for students

name: Lost & Found Pets
description: If you've lost your pet or found someone else's file a report to Miami-Dade Animal Services as soon as possible.

children.text: If you've lost your pet or found someone else, your first step should be to file a report, in person, at the Miami-Dade Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center, which is open seven days a week. (except for County holidays) Animal Services employees are available to help you search in all areas of the facility. Animal Services receives approximately 100 animals and can legally hold found dogs or cats for three days before making them available for adoption.Your quick action is crucial in helping reunite pets with their humans.

keywords: lost pet, search for lost pet, report lost pet, lost dog, lost cat, found dog, found cat, report found dog, report found cat
alternateNames: lost pet, search for lost pet, report lost pet, lost dog, lost cat, found dog, found cat, report found dog, report found cat

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you find a stray pet, bring it to our shelter to be reunited with its owner.

onlineChannels.label: Report a Lost or Found Dog or Cat

name: Get a Pet ID Microchip Implant
description: Microchips provide a unique identification number that links you and your lost or missing pet.

children.text: The simple one-time procedure to install a microchip will prove to be highly beneficial in case your pet gets lost. A microchip is the size of a grain of rice that contains a unique identification number linking you and your pet. Inserting the microchip under your pet's skin is quick, sterile and no more painful than a routine vaccination. Animals can be taken to Animal Services or to most veterinarian offices to check and see if a pet has a microchip. Microchips are especially helpful when a pet's tag is worn and illegible, and for cats clever enough to remove their collar. Bring your pet into the Wellness Clinic at the Pet Adoption and Protection Center to have the microchip inserted as appointments are not necessary.

keywords: Pet Identification, Pet ID, Microchip,

name: Pet Account
description: Each pet has an individual account assigned to them when they receive their rabies vaccination and license.

children.text: Each pet has an individual account assigned to it when it receives their rabies vaccination and license. If you bring your pet into Animal Services to receive one of our vaccination packages or receive a rabies vaccination from your veterinarian, this information is stored in your pet's account. To ensure accurate records and avoid erroneous citations, please contact 311 or report it online to update your pet’s account if any of the following apply: Your contact information has changed, including: Phone number Email address Residential address within Miami-Dade County (PO Boxes are not accepted) The pet passed away Pet surrendered Missing pet Moved out of Miami-Dade County Keeping your information up to date helps us reunite you with your pet if lost and ensures proper communication.

keywords: Pet Account, Update Pet Account, Close Pet Account, Deceased Pet

name: Pet Adoption
description: AllÂ pets adoptedÂ from Miami-Dade Animal Services undergo basic vetting and include sterilization, vaccinations and microchip.

children.text: Thank you for choosing to adopt your new four-legged family member. We invite you to visit the Pet Adoption and Protection Center . Considered a model of best practices in animal housing, the center prioritizes life-saving pet adoptions. The industry leading facility provides an exceptional adoption mall where you can view pets available for adoption and meet them in a comfortable environment. Location: Pet Adoption and Protection Center 3599 NW 79th Avenue Doral, FL 33122 Adoption Mall Hours: Monday - Friday, 10 a.m. - 6:30 p.m. Saturday and Sunday, 9 a.m. - 5 p.m Closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day and all other County-observed holidays.

name: HOPE Express Mobile Adoption
description: The HOPE Express is a mobile pet adoption vehicle that brings shelter pets to a neighborhood near you.

children.text: This mobile pet adoption unit visits communities to find new homes for shelter pets. Helping Our Pets Everyday (HOPE) is the mission of this traveling vehicle and crew.

name: Pet Citations
description: Civil citations are issued to pet owners for failure to comply with County ordinances or laws.

children.text: Civil citations are issued to pet owners for failure to comply with County ordinances or laws. If you receive a notice and would like to dispute it, you may schedule a hearing.

Closed on County holidays.
No appointment is required during walk-in hours.

name: Pet Donations
description: Your donation will help us to expand services like medical care, pet enrichment and finding new homes for thousands of pets.

children.text: Help homeless pets. Your donation to the Animal Services Trust Fund is a great way to express your love and compassion for animals and ensure that orphaned and abandoned pets have the best chance at a better life. Your donation will help us to expand services like medical care, pet enrichment and finding new homes for thousands of pets.  Through your generosity, you will touch the lives of dogs, cats, puppies and kittens who eagerly await forever homes. Ready to change the lives of homeless pets? Make a  donation online now.  More ways to help Our staff, volunteers and foster parents are always in need of supplies to make the pets they help care for as comfortable as possible during their stay at the shelter or in a foster home. Here are other ways you can help to better the lives of animals: Our Amazon.com wish list . In-kind donations. Some examples include: Blankets Towels Plastic pet carriers Flea medication for dogs and cats Toys suitable for sanitizing In-kind donations are accepted on-site at the Pet Adoption and Protection Center located at 3599 NW 79 Ave. in Doral. Drop off anytime Monday through Friday 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 10 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.

keywords: Pet Donations, Help Homeless Pets, Help Animals, Help Shelter Pets

name: Pet Euthanasia and Disposal
description: Humane euthanasia services are offered for animals suffering from medical conditions that can't be cured or treated.

children.text: Animal Services offers humane euthanasia for owned pets suffering incurable illness and disease resulting in significantly diminished quality of life. Animal Services reserves the right to refuse service if the pet is not ill or suffering.  You can also bring a deceased animal to the Pet Adoption and Protection Center for disposal of the remains.

keywords: euthanasia dog, euthanasia cat, put dog down, put cat down, put pet to sleep,humane euthanasia
alternateNames: owner requested euthanasia, put dog down, put dog to sleep, put cat to sleep

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you are 18 years of age or older, you can adopt a pet from our Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

name: Pet Preparedness During a Hurricane
description: Animal Services operates pet-friendly shelters during emergencies. Pre-registration is not required to use the evacuation center.

children.text: Hurricane season runs from June 1 through November 30. Whatever preparation plans you make for yourself, remember to include your pets. If you're riding out the storm in the home of a family member, friend or neighbor, take your pets with you. If You Stay Home If you stay at home, remember to stay together. Keep your pet in a crate or carrier and find a safe area where you will all be together. Keep their collar and tag on in case you get separated. It's always best to microchip your pets since they tend to lose their collars. Pet owners residing in an evacuation zone, unsafe structure or trailer are encouraged to come to a pet-friendly evacuation center. Before disaster strikes, pet owners are encouraged to review the Animal Supplies Checklist to learn how to prepare pets before, during and after a disaster. Pet-Friendly Evacuation Centers Animal Services operates pet-friendly shelters during emergencies. Pre-registration is not required to use the evacuation center. Evacuation centers will be announced as needed.  Upon arrival at the center, pets will be examined by a licensed veterinarian to determine if the pet presents a safety risk. Any pet deemed a risk will not be allowed to enter the evacuation center.

keywords: pet-friendly, pet, friendly, evacuation, center, shelter, storm, hurricane, preparedness, dog, cats, birds, ferrets, gerbils, guinea pigs, hamsters, mice, rats, rabbits

name: Pet Retention Program
description: The Pet Retention Program can help provide pet owners with resources that may help them to keep the pet in their home.

children.text: Faced with having to leave your pet at a shelter can be heartbreaking, but there are alternatives. We will work with you to find resources and solutions that can keep you and your pet together. We also offer rehoming assistance to help you find the best home for your beloved pet and keep them from having to enter the stressful shelter environment. Surrendering your pet to an open admission shelter should be your last resort.

The Pet Retention program can help provide you with the resources to help overcome the barriers to keeping your pet. Animal Services staff will work with you to help prevent you from surrendering your pets, while helping to ease the stray population and space at the Pet Adoption and Protection Center. In the email , please include the following information: Pet owner's name Pet owner's phone number Pet owner's email Pet name, dog or cat, and age

The Pet Deferment program offers options to help you rehome your pet and avoid having to relinquish your dog or cat at the shelter. In some cases, we administer free DHPP and Bordetella vaccines and owners are asked to hold on to their pets for one to two weeks, after which time the owner comes back to the shelter and surrenders their pet if a solution to keeping or rehoming the pet has not been reached. Animal Services staff works with pet owners on a case-by-case basis to provide this service. For more information,  email us or call 311.

publicHours.notes: Closed last Friday of every month

name: Pet Safety
description: Learn tips to keep your pets safe.

children.text: Did you know? Chocolate may be your favorite treat but these treats should stay in the hands of people and not pets. Chocolate is a potent stimulant that can produce potentially life threatening toxic effects in your pet. Your pet might begin to vomit, have diarrhea, experience nervousness and anxiety that could possibly lead to death. Here are some more tips to keep your pets safe.

keywords: pet safety tips, 4th of july tips, halloween tips, holiday pet safety tips

name: Pets During a Hurricane
description: Animal Services operates pet-friendly shelters during emergencies. Pre-registration is not required to use the evacuation center.

children.text: Hurricane season runs from June 1 through November 30. Whatever preparation plans you make for yourself, remember to include your pets. If you're riding out the storm in the home of a family member, friend or neighbor, take your pets with you. If You Stay Home If you stay at home, remember to stay together. Keep your pet in a crate or carrier and find a safe area where you will all be together. Keep their collar and tag on in case you get separated. It's always best to microchip your pets since they tend to lose their collars. Pet owners residing in an evacuation zone, unsafe structure or trailer are encouraged to come to a pet-friendly evacuation center. Before disaster strikes, pet owners are encouraged to review the Animal Supplies Checklist to learn how to prepare pets before, during and after a disaster. Pet-Friendly Evacuation Centers Animal Services operates pet-friendly shelters during emergencies. Pre-registration is not required to use the evacuation center. Evacuation centers will be announced as needed.  Upon arrival at the center, pets will be examined by a licensed veterinarian to determine if the pet presents a safety risk. Any pet deemed a risk will not be allowed to enter the evacuation center.

name: Pet Surrender
description: Surrendering your pet dog or cat is a serious decision. Before you consider doing it, review some potential alternatives.

children.text: Due to critical capacity and the high number of dogs and cats in need of homes Animal Services is asking our community to help us continue our life-saving mission by helping us manage our pet population and avoid surrendering pets unless absolutely necessary. Anyone who finds friendly stray pets should consider fostering them while helping to reunite the pet with their families. Please visit Lost and Found Pets for additional information and tips to help the pet find their way back home. Leaving your pet at a shelter can be a heartbreaking experience, but there are alternatives. We will work with you to find resources and solutions to keep you and your pet together. Surrendering your pet to a shelter should be your last resort. Animal Services works with rescue groups, humane societies and offers rehoming assistance. Before surrendering your pet, try to find a good home for it by asking family and friends, sharing it online, or putting up flyers at veterinarian offices in your neighborhood. Try using resources like Home To Home ™, an interactive platform created to help families, people and pets with the difficult task of finding a new home. Once your profile is created people interested in fostering or adopting a new pet can view your pet profile on Home To Home and then reach out to you directly.

keywords: Pet surrender, pet retention program.

name: Pet Vaccinations
description: Low-cost vaccinations are available for your dogs and cats at the Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

children.text: Miami-Dade Animal Services (ASD) offers low cost rabies vaccines and low cost well-care vaccine packages for the pets of County residents. Well-care packages include vaccines to help protect dogs and cats from many common, serious and even fatal diseases. Dogs and cats must be four months old. Services are provided on a walk-in basis. No appointments.

keywords: pet, vaccinations, shots rabies, vaccinations, dogs, cats, Rabies Vaccination, Vaccination Packages, animal vaccines
alternateNames: pet, vaccinations, shots rabies, vaccinations, dogs, cats, Rabies Vaccination, Vaccination Packages, animal vaccines, animal well care

serviceImage.imageAlt: ASD offers residents low-cost pet care packages which include vaccinations, micro-chips and spay/neuter surgeries.

onlineChannels.label: Request Pet Medical and Vaccine Records

name: Report Animal Problems
description: Report an abandoned or injured animal, animal cruelty, animal bites, a dead animal pickup, and more.

children.text: If you witness any of the conditions below, you can either submit a  report online or call 311. We will open an investigation to ensure your concerns are handled. Report a stray dog Stray dogs can be reported to Animal Services (stray cat reports not accepted). The department will attempt to pick up the stray dog within 24 hours. If the dog is on any expressway, please call FHP at *347. Request a dead animal pickup Animal Services will only pick up a dead animal on the public right-of-way. Owners are responsible to remove dead animals from private property. Request a pet account update Each pet has an account assigned to them when they receive their rabies vaccination and license for the first time. If your pet is lost, passed away, moved or given away, you should update your account to prevent getting a citation. Report an injured animal If you see a dog that has been possibly hit by a car, please contact us immediately so we can respond. We respond to injured animals as a priority.    Report animal cruelty We will investigate signs of cruelty. The most common signs include tick or flea infestations, no food or water, no shelter, injured and not taken to a vet for care, extremely thin or missing hair. Report an abandoned animal Pets that are left behind after the owner or tenant moves. If a dog is left locked inside a car, please contact the police for immediate assistance.    Report a tethered dog It is not legal to keep a dog tied up. We will investigate and educate the owner about this regulation.    Report a dangerous dog If a dog has attacked a person or another domestic animal, submit a report so we can open an investigation. Report breeder, pet store or kennel Animal Services is responsible for the intake and investigation of complaints against pet breeders and shops. Investigations of complaints about breeders or pet stores usually take about 30 days to complete. For a complaint about the purchase of a sick dog or cat from a pet store or breeder, please contact the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Division of Animal Industry at 850-410-0900.

alternateNames: Abandoned Animal, Animal Bite, Animal Cruelty, Dangerous Dog, Dead Animal Pickup, dog tag check, Status of Dog License, Injured Animal, Complaint about a Pet Seller, Pet Seller Complaint, Tethered Dog, chained dog, injured cat, injured dog, dog bite, cat bite, dog attack

serviceImage.imageAlt: File reports about Abandoned Animals, Bites, Cruelty, Dangerous Dogs, Dead Animal Pickup, Pet Sellers and more.

children.text: If you or someone else suffered a bite from a dog or cat, please report it by completing the Animal Bite Report . You will be asked to leave your name and phone number so that Animal Services can be dispatched to investigate. Pease note: All animal bite cases should be referred to the Florida Department of Health in Miami-Dade County at 305-324-2400.
You can search an address in Miami-Dade County to see if a dog has been declared dangerous. Miami-Dade County Dangerous Dog Search

name: Illegal Roadside Animal Sales
description: You can report illegal roadside animal sales  in Miami-Dade County.

children.text: It is illegal to sell, offer for sale, or display for sale any dog or cat within any right-of-way in Miami-Dade County.  You can report illegal roadside sales of dogs or cats to Miami-Dade County Animal Services. It is essential to provide as many details as possible: the perpetrator's name, the vehicle license plate number, the vehicle's description, the location of the sale, a description of the activity, the animal and photos and video when filing a report.

keywords: Report Illegal Roadside Animal Sales,  sale any dog on roadside,  sale any cat on roadside,

name: Spay or Neuter Surgery for Pets
description: Low-cost spay or neuter services are offered to Miami-Dade County residents for cats and dogs.

children.text: The terms spay or neuter refer to the surgical sterilization of an animal. Female animals are spayed by having their ovaries and uterus removed under general anesthesia. Male animals are neutered by having their testicles removed under general anesthesia. After either surgery, the cat or dog is unable to reproduce. Having your dog or cat sterilized can help your pet live a longer, healthier life and also reduce the number of unwanted animals brought into shelters. Appointments for low-cost spay or neuter services are available for pet dogs and cats at Animal Services Doral and Homestead locations. Please schedule your appointment up to 14 days in advance.

keywords: spay, neuter, sterilize dog, sterilize cat, animal sterilization surgery, pet fixed, dog fixed, cat fixed, low-cost spay, low-cost neuter, low cost spay, low cost neuter.
alternateNames: pet sterilization,  pet fixed, cat fixed, spay or neuter, spay or neuter surgery

serviceImage.imageAlt: Spay and neuter surgeries for cats and dogs are available for a low cost.

name: Stray Animals
description: Stray dogs can be reported to Animal Services, stray or feral cats are not picked up.

children.text: Miami-Dade County has a law prohibiting stray dogs. If you see a dog roaming free, carefully try to determine if the animal is a stray. A well-groomed dog or friendly cat may have wandered away from its owner. If you can approach the animal safely check for an ID tag.  The department will attempt to pick up the stray dog within 48 hours. If the dog is on any expressway, please call FHP at *347.  If the dog is in the immediate area of a school, or within a fenced school area, call Miami-Dade School Police at 305-995-2677. Animal Services does not respond to complaints of stray or feral cats and there is no law prohibiting stray cats. Unlike dogs, cats are not confined and can move freely among multiple homes, communities and caretakers. Feral cats are frightened of people, exhibit wild behavior and usually cannot be acclimated to indoor life as a pet and adopted. The most effective way to control the population of un-owned neighborhood cats is through Animal Services free Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return or (TNVR) program.

keywords: Stray animals, stray dogs, trap-neuter-vaccinate-return, stray cats, animal cruelty, animal traps, TNR, TNVR, stray cat sterilization, stray kittens, abandoned animals, abandoned kittens
alternateNames: Stray animals, stray dogs, trap-neuter-vaccinate-return, stray cats, animal cruelty, animal traps, TNR, TNVR, stray cat sterilization, stray kittens, abandoned animals, abandoned kittens, loose dog in school yard, feral cats, dog on highway, stray puppy

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you are 18 years of age or older, you can adopt a pet from our Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

name: Dog or Cat Tag Transfer
description: You can transfer the ownership of a dog or cat from one person to another at the Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

children.text: You can transfer the ownership of a dog or cat from one person to another at the Animal Services Pet Adoption and Protection Center. A completed Transfer of Ownership form is required if a dog or cat is being transferred to another county in Florida. As a result, your pet's Miami-Dade account will be closed. Dog or Cat Tags The dog's or cat's old tag number will be transferred and valid until its expiration date. A new tag will be required only if the existing tag has expired. If the new owner decides to purchase a new tag prior to the old tag's expiration, the fee will not be prorated. Full price must be paid.

name: Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return for Community Cats
description: The free Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return Program is an effective and humane way to stabilize the homeless cat population

children.text: The free Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return (TNVR) Program is an effective and humane way to stabilize the cat population with free spay or neuter surgeries for free roaming cats commonly referred to as community cats. Miami-Dade County residents can use their own trap to capture a cat and then take it to the Pet Adoption and Protection Center.  Cats that are brought in will be sterilized, vaccinated for rabies and given a booster FRCPC (Feline Rhinotracheitis, Calicivirus, Panleukopenia and Chlamydophila) vaccination, then marked with an ear tip to show he or she has been sterilized. You can choose to have the cat returned to you or to the area where you picked it up. Any cats not picked up from the Pet Adoption and Protection Center after several days will be released back to the community from which they came. Injured or diseased cats are not released back into the community. Residents can also bring community cats to local participating veterinarians for free as part of Animal Services' partnerships with the Miami Veterinary Foundation. Residents must schedule appointments directly with the veterinary provider of their choice.

keywords: Trap, Neuter, Vaccinate, Trap Neuter Vaccinate Return, TNVR, Spay, Trap-Neuter-Vaccinate-Return, street cats, homeless cats, neighborhood cats, feral cats

serviceImage.imageAlt: If you are 18 years of age or older, you can adopt a pet from our Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

publicHours.notes: TNVR services are not available on County holidays.

name: Volunteer at Animal Services
description: Donate your time and make a positive impact on the lives of animals.

children.text: You can learn about pet care, make new friends that share a passion for animals, and have tons of fun, all while making a positive impact on the lives of animals. We welcome volunteers who would like to donate their time and are interested in making a difference. Your participation and fresh ideas can help toward finding forever loving homes for all abandoned dogs and cats. All volunteers receive training and orientation. There are many volunteer positions you may be interested in helping with.

keywords: volunteer, donate your time, Animal Services, internship, kitten kuddler

name: Kitten Cuddler Volunteer
description: Tiny, orphaned newborn kittens need round-the-clock care. You can help them by becoming a kitten cuddler.

children.text: Tiny, orphaned newborn kittens need round-the-clock care to stay alive. We are recruiting foster parents to help care for and feed the very young kittens abandoned at the Pet Adoption and Protection Center.

keywords: kitten cuddler, bottle feeding, newborn kittens, abandoned newborn kittens, kitten cuddler program, kitten cuddler training,
